On 28 August 2013 14:15, Ken Lloyd <kalloyd@...> wrote:
>
> If I un=
derstand your approach correctly, this sounds interesting.  I wish to
> cla=
rify your use of some terms derived from the term =93space=94, and
> specif=
ically =93behavioural space=94 and =93geographical space=94.  Is the first =
a
> morphism or perhaps a mapping onto or between spaces? Is the second
> d=
escriptive of shapes between degrees of freedom and regions?  For example,
=
> are these terms generally referring to topological or manifold spaces?


=
> Coming from a foundation of category theory, I=92ve found it dangerous fo=
r me
> to assume what one means by =93geographical space=94, because it mig=
ht be
> limited to a particular Cartesian physical world-space.

In some wa=
ys 'geographical space' is a misleading term because
initially I want to ha=
ve a continuous, bounded, homogeneous space with
real numbered coords (i.e.=
 not a grid). Then again, it's a useful
metaphor that suggests ideas for fu=
ture research, i.e. adding
structure to the space that we can think of as v=
aguely analogous to
oceans, mountains, grass plains, deserts, islands, etc.=


A better term for behavioural space migth be 'strategy' space, to the
ext=
ent that any evolved agent can be considered to be executing some
strategy,=
 from bacteria all the way up to mammals and people - at the
highest level =
we can say they are each executing some survival
strategy, and where there =
are similarities we can say that two
strategies are proximate in strategy s=
pace - but how you define that
space is tricky, hence I'm kicking that prob=
lem down the road.

Colin.


>
>
>
> I would agree that topological and oth=
er meaningful, spatial domains *are*
> missing from NEAT-based search space=
s, and that these might affect the
> directions of evolution.
>
>
>
> Also,=
 I think the notion of substitutability with various, alternate
> =93module=
s=94, categories of classes, is an excellent developmental approach.
> Even=
 these can be evolved.

> Subject: [neat] Request for Comments: Geographic=
al and Behavioural Space
> Considerations
>
>
>
>
>
> Hi all,
>
> I'm start=
ing to think about direction for the next SharpNEAT
> iteration. There's be=
en a lot of talk recently about novelty search
> versus objective search, a=
nd maybe mixtures of the two. I myself
> talked about how in the natural wo=
rld organisms are separated in both
> behavioural space (i.e. novel behavio=
ur is less likely to compete for
> the same resources as existing behaviour=
s) but also geographical
> space, and I think that geographical space is a =
key factor that is
> missing from NEAT based search currently, and possibly=
 EC as a whole,
> with the caveat there may be other research groups with w=
ork in that
> area that I'm unaware of.
>
> My current plan is to focus on =
this geographical space idea for this
> iteration because it is the simples=
t to implement. Dealing with
> behavioural space is potentially more compli=
cated because how to
> compare behaviour varies across problem domains and =
how you identify
> the key factors to compare is probably a non-trivial pro=
blem. I want
> to try and tackle this at some point, but I'm also keen to e=
xplore the
> geo-space idea.
>
> What does this all mean in practical terms=
?
>
> SharpNEAT is a kit of parts that allows you to swap in replacement
> =
parts such as an alternative genetic representation and/or associated
> gen=
etic operators (recombination, mutation, etc) with minimal impact
> on othe=
r parts in the kit (in principle anyway). I'm proposing to
> provide an alt=
ernative evolution algorithm class that replaces NEAT's
> genome based spec=
iation (which clusters genomes into K clusters in
> genetic space), with a =
geographical space alternative (I'll call it
> geo-space for short).
>
> Th=
e idea is that we have some cartesian/euclidean space (probably a
> square =
2D space initially to keep the code simple, but 3D or 'globe'
> space (2-sp=
here) are reasonable alternatives). The seed genomes are
> each assigned a =
random coord in the geo-space and this will be fixed
> for the life of that=
 genome. So we are basically adding a physical
> attribute to the genome su=
ch that our population members are probably
> better referred to as organis=
ms (or agents or population members).
> I'll use 'agent' because it's easie=
r to type :)
>
> Agent fitness is now adjusted by population density at the=
 agent's
> geo-location, this allows really bad agents to survive so long a=
s they
> are in a sparse region of geo-space, thus allowing for some divers=
ity
> of the genome pool.
>
> Reproduction - I haven't put much thought int=
o this but the two
> options I see are to create offspring agents near to t=
heir parent(s)
> versus randomly scattered. Probably some 'dispersion' vari=
able will
> define the amount of scattering with 0 being atop of the parent=
 (or
> between the two?) and 1 being totally random. (Question: Is e.g. see=
d
> scattering in nature gaussian?). Clearly if agent's are spawned near
> =
their parent's we would expect to see clusters of agent's with similar
> be=
haviour, and that clustering will increase population density and
> therefo=
re lower the fitness of agent's in that cluster. So there is a
> form of fi=
tness sharing going on, but as I say, I haven't really
> thought through th=
e implications and dynamics of that. But it would be
> interesting to set u=
p, play with and observe what happens.
>
> Factoring in behavioural space c=
onsiderations should be possible at a
> later date, e.g. fitness at a geo-l=
ocation is not adjusted down if an
> agent has novel behaviour compared to =
other agent's at that
> geo-location.
>
> As per usual - any thoughts and f=
eedback are welcome.
>
> Colin
